title: Cognitive Rehabilitation for Occupational Therapists | Singapore Institute of Technology

meta.description: This course equips occupational therapists with skills in occupational therapy-centric cognitive-perceptual assessments, problem identification, goal setting, and intervention plans.

text_lines: Browse Professional Exams and Preparatory Courses
Browse Professional Exams and Preparatory Courses
This course equips occupational therapists with skills in occupational therapy-centric cognitive-perceptual assessments, problem identification, goal setting, and intervention plans.
Health Sciences, Adult and Geriatric Rehabilitation, Occupational Therapy
This workshop focuses on the knowledge and skills supporting occupational therapy practice for cognitive-perceptual issues seen in persons with a range of neurological and psychiatric conditions.
It is also a continuation of the two-day inter-professional primer on cognitive rehabilitation.
The workshop aims to provide you with the knowledge and skills in occupational therapy centric cognitive-perceptual assessments, problem identification, goal setting, and intervention plans.

Additionally providing you with the necessary knowledge and skills in various areas related to cognitive and perceptual dysfunctions. These areas include occupation-focused models and approaches, assessments for cognitive and perceptual problems, problem identification and goal setting, and intervention strategies and plans.
Occupational therapists that are working or will work with adults with cognitive perceptual problems
AHPC registered occupational therapist and participants who completed the course
"Inter-professional Workshop on Cognitive Rehabilitation for Persons with Cognitive-Perceptual Dysfunction"
To apply treatment models and approaches to cases involving cognitive and/or perceptual issues
To administer cognitive-perceptual assessments and interpret results
To use metacognitive strategy and other evidence-based approaches in occupational therapy interventions across various clinical settings
To apply occupational therapy treatment approaches to executive dysfunction, memory, spatial neglect, apraxia and visual-perceptual deficits
Adjunct Clinical Professor, Cognitive Science in Rehabilitation Medicine, Weill Cornell Medical College, New York; Professor and Dean, School of Health and Natural Sciences, Mercy College, New York
Adjunct Clinical Professor, Cognitive Science in Rehabilitation Medicine, Weill Cornell Medical College, New York; Professor and Dean, School of Health and Natural Sciences, Mercy College, New York

Joan Toglia, Ph.D, OTR/L, FAOTA is internationally recognised as a leader in cognitive rehabilitation and occupational therapy. She is Adjunct Clinical Professor of Cognitive Science in Rehabilitation Medicine at Weill Cornell Medical College, New York; Professor of Occupational Therapy and Dean Emerita of the School of Health and Natural Sciences at Mercy College, New York.

Dr. Toglia has over 35 years of experience in Occupational Therapy, with a specialisation in neurorehabilitation and cognitive impairments following acquired brain injury. Dr. Toglia has taught over 300 workshops and lectures on cognitive rehabilitation to clinicians throughout the United States and around the world including Canada, Europe, Israel, Asia, South Africa, and South America. Her research and publications have focused on theory, assessment methods, and intervention strategies to support and optimise cognitive function across different populations.

She has authored or co-authored over 80 publications including books, assessment tools, journal articles, and book chapters. Dr. Toglia has been recognised for her leadership and contributions to Cognitive Rehabilitation Theory and Practice by the American Occupational Therapy Association through an Achievement Award and appointment to the Roster of Fellows of the American Occupational Therapy Association.
Key components, assessment and intervention methods, clinical applications of models and approaches used in Occupational Therapy
CO-OP model – Dynamic Interactional Model and The Multicontext Approach
Identifying models and approaches – from clinical cases and videos (interactive activity)
The use of technology and software for the management of cognitive perceptual dysfunction and examples of how it applies across models
Clinical Reasoning: case applications of the use of treatment models and approaches (small group activity)
Identifying the type of information needed from assessment
Deciding where to begin in the assessment
Different types of assessments and purposes
Understanding the client's perspective and goals
Interpreting Cognitive Screening: MoCA and relationship to function - other screening tools
Overview of other tools (eg. Rivermead Behavioral Memory Test)
The Contextual Memory Test – online and interpretation
Assessments for lower-level patients (below the level of standardised assessment)
Case application of assessment selection, problem identification, and treatment goal setting in acute care
Homework (review assessment websites as per instructions in handouts)
Basic ADL and IADL Performance-Based assessment and interactive activity
Examples of Performance Based Assessments: Performance Assessment of Self-Care Skills – (PASS) IADL subtests, Executive Function Performance Test (video) and other tools
Case application: assessment selection, problem identification, and treatment goal setting in subacute care
Performance-based Assessment and Error Analysis tools
Weekly Calendar Planning Activity (WCPA) – video illustration
Interpretation and documentation of assessment results
Clinical Reasoning behind selection of assessments
Case application: assessment selection, problem identification, and treatment goal setting in community care
Homework (practice assessment administration - see handout for instructions)
Metacognitive Strategy Approaches (Co-Op, Multi-context) and Evidence
Overview of the key components of the MC approach
Analysis of cognitive-perceptual demands of activities
Manipulating functional cognitive activities to provide an optimal cognitive challenge (interactive activity)
Combining cognitive and motor goals with functional cognitive activities
Case applications in sub-acute (inpatient) of occupational therapy intervention strategies for executive dysfunction
Use of a Metacognitive Framework within functional activities
Mediation: guidelines for facilitating awareness, self-regulation, and executive thinking – video illustrations
Selection and integration of treatment methods
Video illustrations and case applications of Metacognitive Strategy Training: community setting
Practical applications: case problem solving: occupational therapy intervention strategies for memory, awareness, and executive dysfunction (small group activity)
Documenting Functional Goals, Progress, and Outcomes
Discussion and homework - review cases in handouts
Specific assessment tools for neglect and visual perception
Application of different OT treatment approaches to Spatial Neglect, Apraxia, and Visual Perceptual deficits
Group case presentations across different settings – acute care, sub-acute or inpatient Rehabilitation and outpatient, community
Summary of the Evidence in Cognitive Rehabilitation
Recap summary of course - putting in all together
A Certificate of Participation will be issued to participants who
Attend at least 75% of the course
Undertake and pass non-credit bearing assessment during the course

Description: Participants will need to develop an assessment and treatment plan for a patient with cognitive impairments, based on the knowledge and skills learnt from the training. They must highlight the assessment approaches, treatment goals, intervention plan, and treatment outcomes. Through this assessment, participants must demonstrate the ability to consolidate clinical knowledge with application principles.

Justification: Throughout the workshop, participants will be taught various cognitive rehabilitation approaches, assessments and intervention strategies. This assessment will allow them to consolidate their learning by going through the assessment and treatment processes, thereby demonstrating that they have understood and can apply the principles and skills learnt.
The full fee for this course is S$3,052.00.
All fees above include GST. GST applies to individuals and Singapore-registered companies.

Improving Patient Outcomes through Advanced Clinical Supervision Competency

The Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) taps on evidence-based education practices to address the increasing demand for advanced clinical supervision competencies among Allied Health Professionals and improve patient outcomes.
Health Sciences, Adult and Geriatric Rehabilitation, Competency-based Education
Shedding Light on Workplace Safety in Social Services
These niche courses equip professionals in social service agencies with the skills to optimise health and safety at the workplace.
Health Sciences, Social Sciences, Workplace Safety and Health
Armed with a Postgraduate Diploma in Sonography, Florence Tan is ready for advanced clinical practice and leadership.
Redefining Thinking and Learning at SkillsFuture Festival

The annual SkillsFuture Festival to promote lifelong learning was hosted by the Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) this year on 23 July. Riding on the theme of ‘Design for the Future Economy’, the single-day event featured 53 learning workshops and talks, with SIT faculty staff sharing their expert insights on thinking and learning.
Design Innovation, Leadership and Communication, Health Sciences
With the ageing population in Singapore, there has been a paradigm shift from structured institutionalised care to a more person-centric approach.
Health Sciences, Adult and Geriatric Rehabilitation, Design Innovation
As Singapore's ageing population continues to grow, care for the elderly is becoming a pressing issue.
Health Sciences, Adult and Geriatric Rehabilitation
This intensive workshop provides theoretical and practical skills in small parts ultrasound, including scrotal, penile, thyroid, parathyroid, salivary glands, and lymph nodes.

This intensive workshop provides theoretical and practical skills in breast ultrasound and imaging of lumps and bumps, including intervention work, advanced imaging techniques, and interpretation of abnormal findings.
This workshop provides advanced theoretical knowledge and practical skills for sonographers in paediatric and neonatal ultrasound, including imaging techniques and diagnostic processes.
Interprofessional Low Vision Rehabilitation: Basic Foundations
This course equips healthcare professionals to manage low vision patients, develop assessment skills, support psychosocial adjustment and more.
Occupational Therapy, Physiotherapy, Nursing, Health Sciences
This course is designed to equip AHP clinical supervisors and educators with the skills to provide effective clinical training to AHPs and students.
Adult and Geriatric Rehabilitation, Health Sciences
Functional Fitness Screening and Falls Efficacy Prescription for Older Adults
This course equips learners to help older adults maintain fitness, manage fall risks, and improve independence and well-being.
